title: Quiz 1: FQE June 2017 Paper II
description: Past paper from June 2017 FQE covering MCQs and Clinical Scenarios in Reproductive Health.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT useful in the diagnosis of premature rupture of membranes?

options.text: Demonstration of amniotic fluid on speculum examination

questions.explanation: While methylene blue can theoretically diagnose membrane rupture (by injection into the amniotic sac), it is invasive and generally not used for routine diagnosis. Standard non-invasive methods include observing leakage (pooling), the Fern test (crystallization pattern), and Nitrazine test (pH).
questions.hint: Think about which test involves an invasive injection versus non-invasive observation.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about lochia?

options.text: Lochia loss can mimic post-partum hemorrhage
Rubra occur up to the 10th day

questions.explanation: Excessive lochia can be confused with PPH. Lochia Alba is white/yellow (not red). Lochia Rubra (red) lasts 3-4 days (not 10). Lochia is normal, but foul-smelling lochia is a sign of infection.
questions.hint: Consider the volume of discharge and how it might be confused with abnormal bleeding.

questions.question: One of the following is NOT a sign of placental separation:

options.text: There is fresh flow of blood per vagina

questions.explanation: Signs of placental separation include lengthening of the cord, the fundus rising (and becoming hard/globular), and a gush of blood. The cord does not shorten.
questions.hint: What happens to the cord when the placenta detaches and drops into the lower segment?

questions.question: During second stage of labour the cervical dilatation is:
questions.explanation: The second stage of labor begins at full cervical dilatation (10 cm) and ends with the expulsion of the fetus.
questions.hint: This stage ends with the delivery of the baby.

questions.question: Diabetes in pregnancy is associated with an increased risk of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Gestational diabetes typically causes fetal macrosomia (large baby) due to high glucose levels, leading to risks like shoulder dystocia and C-section. IUGR is typically associated with pre-existing diabetes with vascular complications, but in the context of 'Diabetes in pregnancy' (GDM), macrosomia is the hallmark.
questions.hint: Does high sugar usually make the baby smaller or larger?

questions.question: Anaemia in pregnancy is mostly due to:
questions.explanation: Iron deficiency is the most common cause of anemia in pregnancy globally due to increased fetal demands and hemodilution.
questions.hint: Which micronutrient demand increases significantly for red blood cell production?

questions.question: Immunological test for diagnosis of pregnancy:
questions.explanation: Tests detecting Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (HCG) in serum or urine are immunological tests. Ultrasound is a biophysical/imaging method.
questions.hint: Which test detects a hormone using antibodies?

questions.question: About augmentation of labour:

options.text: Oxytocin is given as an IV bolus
Oxytocin is the drug of choice titrated against the contraction

questions.explanation: Augmentation uses Oxytocin via controlled IV infusion (titrated). IV bolus can cause uterine rupture. Cytotec is typically for induction/cervical ripening. Ergometrine causes titanic contractions and is used for PPH, not augmentation.
questions.hint: The drug must be strictly controlled to match contraction strength.

questions.question: The following are signs of fetal distress EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Normal fetal pH is 7.35-7.45. Acidosis (pH < 7.2) is a sign of distress. Meconium and hypoxia are associated with distress.
questions.hint: Look for the normal physiological value.

questions.question: The following is a positive manifestation of pregnancy:
questions.explanation: Positive (diagnostic) signs are indisputable evidence of a fetus (Fetal heart sounds, Fetal movement felt by examiner, Ultrasound visualization). Nausea (presumptive) and Hegar's sign (probable) are not positive signs.
questions.hint: Which sign provides undeniable proof of a fetus?

questions.question: Common cause of UTI in pregnancy is:
questions.explanation: E. coli is the most common pathogen causing UTIs in pregnancy due to anatomical proximity and urinary stasis.
questions.hint: This bacteria is common in the GI tract.

questions.question: Biophysical profile constitute the following:
questions.explanation: BPP includes 5 parameters: Fetal Tone, Fetal Movement (Motor response), Fetal Breathing, Amniotic Fluid Volume, and Non-Stress Test (Heart rate).
questions.hint: Think about what indicates the baby is active and moving.

questions.question: The following is a complication for multiple pregnancy:
questions.explanation: Multiple pregnancies are associated with malpresentations and polyhydramnios, increasing the risk of cord prolapse. They are usually associated with preterm labor (not prolonged) and low birth weight.
questions.hint: Consider the space constraints and potential for malpresentation.

questions.question: Regarding cervical incompetence in pregnancy:

options.text: Patterns of abortion are in ascending manner
Present with acute painful per vaginal bleeding
Mc Donald suture (cervical cerclage) is best performed at 14 weeks

questions.explanation: Cerclage is typically placed at 12-14 weeks. Cervical incompetence presents with painless dilatation/expulsion (not painful bleeding).
questions.hint: When is the optimal time for a prophylactic cerclage?

questions.question: Concerning vaginal birth after caesarian section (VBAC) delivery:

options.text: Indicated in a woman with two previous scars
Possible in a mother with one previous scar due to fetal distress
Possible in a mother with contracted pelvis

questions.explanation: VBAC is generally safe for one previous scar if the indication was non-recurrent (like fetal distress). It is contraindicated in 2+ scars or recurrent causes like contracted pelvis.
questions.hint: Is fetal distress a recurrent condition?

questions.question: Joan, a 35-year-old para 5+0 g6, presented with ruptured membranes and pulsating cord prolapse in the health center. How will you manage Joan until she arrives in the level 4 facility?

options.text: Place her in exaggerated lithotomy position
Prepare her for caesarean section if the cord has stopped pulsating

questions.explanation: The immediate management for cord prolapse is to relieve pressure on the cord. This is achieved by the Knee-chest position or Exaggerated Sim's position to maintain fetal circulation.
questions.hint: Which position uses gravity to move the presenting part off the cord?

questions.question: The following are indications of elective caesarean section: (Select all that apply)

options.text: Breech presentation in 2nd stage of labour

questions.explanation: Two previous scars and known CPD are absolute indications for elective CS. Transverse lie is an indication if it persists to term/labor. Breech in 2nd stage is usually delivered vaginally (assisted breech) or emergency CS.
questions.hint: Look for absolute indications where vaginal delivery is contraindicated.

questions.question: Concerning malaria in pregnancy: (Select all that apply)

options.text: Is severe in non pregnant than in the pregnant mothers
First line treatment is by use of AL
Use of long term insecticides treated nets is not advised

questions.explanation: Malaria is more severe in pregnancy. It causes IUFD, IUGR, and low birth weight. AL is used in 2nd/3rd trimester, but Quinine is often preferred in 1st trimester/severe cases.
questions.hint: Think about the adverse outcomes for the fetus.

questions.question: Observations charted on a partograph include: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Fetal lie is typically recorded in notes but not plotted on the standard partograph grid like Moulding, Dilatation, Contractions, and FHR.
questions.hint: Which parameters are plotted on the graphs?

questions.question: In regard to eclampsia: (Select all that apply)

options.text: Is prevalent in extreme of ages i.e. below 18 and above 35 years
Delivery can be delayed until term
Phenobarbitone is the drug of choice

questions.explanation: Eclampsia is defined by convulsions and occurs in uncontrolled pre-eclampsia. Extremes of age are risk factors. Delivery cannot be delayed. Magnesium Sulfate is the drug of choice.
questions.hint: What is the defining symptom of eclampsia?

questions.question: A mother who is a known diabetic is pregnant and presents to your clinic at 30 weeks gestation. What forms part of your management? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Blood for oral glucose tolerance test
Should be managed as normal pregnancy since she is a known diabetic
Mother should wait for spontaneous onset of labour at term

questions.explanation: Known diabetics need monitoring for pre-eclampsia (proteinuria) and macrosomia (fetal weight). OGTT is for diagnosis (she is already known). They require high-risk management and often induction before term.
questions.hint: What are the common complications of diabetes that need monitoring?
